div.p: 5. Saturday— Minute-Book for Smithson Committee.
Acts of Congress. 25. Congress— 2d. Session.
Library— Pearson’s Introduction to practical Astronomy.
Minutes of yesterday’s meeting.
10. Comee. of Manufactures Adams, Slade, Vail, Kennedy, Biddle, Tillinghast—absent Hunter, Naylor, Elmore

H.R.U.S— Resolution for printing default Documents—motion to strike out document 197. Call of the House moved rejectedto— Motion to strike outrejectedOrder of the day— Bill for extending and improving the navy yard at Brooklyn and for constructing a dry dock at the same— Paynter moved to add a section—100000 dollars for a dry-dock at Philadelphia. Serjeant, Potter, Biddle, Petrikin— Thompson, Elmore, Pickens, C. Shepard, Stanley, Dawson, Hoffman, Ingham—
11. Act for the better Government of the Navy of U.S The Rules and Regulations— U.S. Laws 3. 351. Art: 21.
Articles of War 25. 26. 27. 28. U.S. Laws 4. 17.

14. Monday. H.R.U.S. Harlan moves to take up the Resolution for appointing a Committee to investigate the Swartwout defalcation—lost— The States called for Resolutions; beginning with Iowa— Sherrod Williams offers Resolutions reflecting upon the waste of time by Congress— Maclur moves to lay the Resolutions on the table— I raised the question of consideration, upon the precedent of last week refusing to receive a petition presented by me, as disrespectful to the House— Yeas and Nays—consideration now refused 66 to 93.— Elmore Offers anti-abolition amendments to Resolutions offered last week by C. Cushing— Not in order as Amendment Elmore withdraws and then offers them as Resolutions. I enquired, if they were not included in the Resolutions of 12 Decr.— The Speaker takes time to decide, and the Resolutions lie over— Wise reads a Letter from Lieutt C. G Hunter, and moves a Call on the Department of the Navy for documents affecting Commodore Elliot— Rule suspended and Resolution adopted— Mercer introduces a Bill— Exve.
Curtis’s Resolution for printing 2 additional defalcations, passed without opposition.— Cushing presented Resolutions concerning the distribution of public lands referred to the select Committee— Lincoln calls for information of the payment of debts from Boston Banks— My short Resolution adopted without opposition— Also the Petition of Ann Royall for a pension referred, to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions.— I asked the Clerk for copies of the La Fayette and Smithsonian joint Resolutions.— Evening party at Mr Bodiscos Bal d’Enfans. J. P. Todd’s visit—

15. Rose at 8. O’Clock— Meeting of the Smithsonian Committee— Present Adams, Thompson, Kennedy, Hunter, No Quorum— Thompson made objections to Mr Rush’s proceedings to recover the fund— The Joint Resolution constituting a joint Committee supersedes the authority of the separate Committee of the House. H.R.U.S. Reports from Committees— Cambreleng, from the Comee of Ways of Means moved that they be discharged from the
consideration of a Letter to him, from the Secretary of the Treasury, with a report from the first Comptroller, calling for an explanatory Act of Congress, to settle numerous questions of duties under the compromise revenue act of Feby 1833.—and to refer it to the Committee of Manufactures— I objected to this motion, and it was withdrawn— Reports of Committees absorbed the hour— Connor in the Speaker’s Chair— Question upon the appointment of the Swartwout defalcation Committee Legare, Cushing, Cushman, Hoffman, Thomas, Menefee, Prentiss of Mississippi— Cushing’s Speech, replied to remarks of Robertson, upon the Speaker’s appointment of him— Cushing a member of the select public Land Committee— Underwood— Gratiot’s defalcation— Underwood expatiates on the Amendment of the Constitution proposed by him and moves an adjournment at half past 4—carried. Took Mr Pope home— Snow this morning; and again this Evening— Assorting Letters and Petitions— Mrs A has a hoarse cough— Mine as bad.

16. IV:30. Wednesday— Minutes for Petitions. H.R.U.S. Dromgoole moves a suspension of the Rules to take up his Resolution for substituting viva voce elections in all cases where the ballot is required by the Rules— Wise moves a call of the House— I urge Dromgoole to withdraw motion to suspend the rules, to avoid waste of time— He refuses— Call of the House gone through— Question to suspend the rules 97 to 93. not 2 thirds— Reports from Committees— Order of the day— Underwood concludes his Speech upon his proposed amendment to the Constitution followed by H. Fry.—Biddle—Toucey, Duncan— Motion to adjourn at 5.—yeas and nays— Adjournment carried at 5.— Took Mr Pope home—and W. S. Smith— Mrs Adams confined by illness all day and Evening— Whist

17— Thursday— I was called up between 12 and 1. O’Clock by the extreme illness of Mrs Adams—which continued all Night— I had Mrs Smith and Margaret up, and they remained up with her all Night— Between 4 and 5 I resumed my occupation of assorting my Petitions.

Met the Committee of Manufactures. Present—Adams, Elmore, Vail, Naylor Hunter, Tillinghast. Chairman instructed to report a Bill, granting authority to Francis Gage the permission to import the iron materials for an iron Vessel for an Ocean Navigation—and to the Apalachicola joint Stock company to import the materials for four iron Steamboats. And to ask to be discharged from the further consideration of the Petition ofColgate and others praying for a duty upon Starch, and that it be referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, who have referred to them the Bill reported at the last Session to impose such a duty— Howard from the Committee of foreign Affairs moved to reprint Legare’s report of the last Session upon the Petitions for a Congress of Nations— I moved as an amendment that the Memorial of Origen Bacheler and others referred at this Session, and discussing the last years report of the Committee, should be printed with the report and all recommitted to the Committee— After some discussion with
Howard, Legare and Cushing— I withdrew the motion to recommit, and Petrikin moved and carried 68 to 57 the previous question which cut off my motion to print Origen Bacheler’s Memorial— Order of the day— Duncan took three hours and a half to conclude his furious Speech— He was immediately taken up and severely castigated by Stanley of N.C.— Then some warm debate, a Question between Wise and the Speaker upon the question of viva voce, as amendment to the amendment “by ballot” was in order Wise insisting that it changed a rule of the house, and therefore could not be moved without one days notice— Wise appealed from the decision of the Speaker— Linn Banks explained the practice in the Virginia house of delegates to which W. Cost Johnson replied— Kennedy— Motions to call the House—to adjourn and for the previous question lost— Cambreleng finally moves viva voce, for taking first the question upon Wise’s amendment “by ballot”
Carried 113 to 105— Then motion to adjourn—lost.— Ballot commences for the 9 members at once— 6. chosen at the first ballot—Harlan, Curtis, Wise, Smith, Dawson, Elmore— At the second ballot the other three Hopkins, Hubley and Cushman— Adjourned at 11. P.M.

18. VII— H.R.U.S— Correction of the Journal upon the statement of the Petitions for the importation of iron free of duty for ship-building— Elmore asks to be excused from serving on the investigating Committee; because he considers himself as too independent and impartial— After a debate of an hour and a half he is excused. Then Cushman asks to be excused, because he is a particular friend of the Secretary of the Treasury’s and because of the multitude of his duties on the Committee of Commerce After an hour’s debate he is excused— Then Hubly asks to be excused because he cannot attend the Committee, and because he was not chosen by the votes of his friends— While the yeas and nays were taking
it was circulated that he had received an appointment in Pennsylvania; whereupon about 20 members changed their votes— Excused.— Then a motion to ballot again immediately to fill up the three vacancies— Crary moves to postpone till to-morrow. Yeas and nays called, and Crary withdraws his motion. Call of the House ordered, and then superseded— Second ballot— Martin of Alabama Wagener, and Taylor of New-York were chosen— Taylor asked to be excused, but declined to give his reasons now, and moved an adjournment to give them to-morrow— Adjourned at 7.— Walk home.

19. V:15. Saturday— H.R.U.S— Taylor assigns his reasons for asking to be excused— His incompetency; because he is a Doctor and not a Lawyer— Hiram Gray supports his colleague in a long and fervent speech hot debate— Wise, Prentiss, Eli Moore— Yeas and Nays 102 to 102— Speaker decides in favour of excusing him— Then Wagener asks to be excused, because he was not chosen by the votes
of his own party— Eli Moore says that no democrat will serve upon the Committee, unless chosen by the democracy of the House; or he would be a traitor to his party— Bynum and Wise— Jenifer— Bynum and Stanly— Heat— W. Cost Johnson,—after a Speech moves the previous question, carried Wagener is not excused 105 to 102— Then Martin claims to be excused, being already a member of two Committees— Alias, excuses himself; but not with out making a Speech— Two vacancies to be filled— Hunter of Ohio moves a reconsideration of the vote refusing to excuse Wagener. Not now in order— Ballot to supply the places of Taylor and Martin—201 ballots. Owens has 103. Foster 101.— Hamer 90. Thomas 84. The democracy of the House as Eli Moore calls them wanted Hamer and Thomas, a pair of County Court Pettifoggers—but could not carry the votes (by ballot) of their own party. Thomas had 90 and Hamer 84 votes— One ticket had 3 names upon it and the tellers rejected it as a blank and were sustained by the Speaker— Toucey
said to me that the decision of the Speaker was wrong, for it should have counted as a ticket, making the whole number 202—in which case Foster would not have had a majority and would not have been chosen— Hunter of Ohio, renewed his motion to reconsider the vote refusing to excuse Wagener— Sherrod Williams moved the previous Question— Evans moved to lay the motion on the table. Dromgoole and afterwards Duncan moved to adjourn; and for a call of the House, and for yeas and nays; and for tellers, all which were refused—and Hunter’s motion to reconsider was laid on the table 103 to 66— Wise then asked leave to offer a Resolution, authorising the Committee to employ a Clerk; a printer to print necessary papers, to go to New-York—or elsewhere if necessary, and the members to be absent from the service of the House till they make their report— Beatty and Haynes objected— Wise moved a suspension of the rules, and it was carried 112 to 32— On the Resolution Harlan moved the previous Question and it was carried, and the yeas and nays refused—
The Resolution was carried— Petrikin voted for it—moved a reconsideration—withdrew his motion, and gave notice that he would move it on Monday— Wise immediately moved it himself called the previous question himself; and carried it, and the reconsideration was rejected— Adjourned about 8. O’Clock

20. V:30— Sunday— Heard Mr Fowler A.M. from Revelation 14:13. A funeral discourse on the death of two female parishioners. P.M. at St. John’s. Mr Hawley 2d Sunday after Epiphany— Sermon— Revelation 22.2.

21. V. Monday— H.R.U.S— Petition day. I asked leave to make a Statement granted 117 to 58— The Clerks first counted 115 to 58—mistake corrected Made my Statement, and presented 175 petitions— Vermont Resolutions. debate— Adjourned at 4— Evening at whist

22. V:30. Tuesday— H.R.U.S— Land Bill from the Senate laid on the table—102 to 97.— Cumberland Road Bill. Motion to lay on the table—postponed— Evening at Mr Poinsetts— Captain Matthew C. Perry— Walk home

My Statement made on Monday is in the Intelligencer of this Morning; with a list of Petitions from 160 to 336. H.R.U.S— Petrikin moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday to lay the land graduation Bill from the Senate, on the table— Haynes moved to suspend the Rules for a motion, to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon the President’s Message—101 to 53 not two thirds— Reports of Committees— Bill to renew the Patent of Thomas Blanchard—passed after debate 89 to 72— Questions on Petrikin’s motion to reconsider the vote to lay on the table the graduation Bill— Call of the House, 283 members answered— Lewis Williams moves to lay the motion to reconsider on the table—lost 102 to 96—question to reconsider lost by Sherrod Williams’s changing his vote 98 to 99— Question to lay the Cumberland road Bill on the table lost 77 to 105.— Duelling bill from the Senate referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union who have the House before them. Passed one or two Bills— Adjourned 5— Evening at whist—

V:30. 24. Thursday— Committee of Manufactures. Adams, Slade, Vail,Edward Cook, addressed the Committee on the petition for a duty of 25 per Cent, ad valorem on pins—and the Chairman was instructed to report a Section to that effect as an amendment to the Bill for laying a duty upon Starch.— Also a Section authorising John Calhoun to import free of duty, iron for four Steam-boats— And to ask to be discharged from the consideration of the Resolution offered by O. Titus, and move its reference to the Committee of Ways and Means— H.R.U.S. Clowney from the Committee on the expenditures of the War Department reported a Resolution to demand repayment of 800 dollars allowed by the present Secretary of War toLewis for copying extra Service in that Department in 1818, and if he does not repay that the Attorney General be directed to commence a suit to recover the money— Debate thereon— M’Kay, opposes the Report— Clowney’s Speech— Everett moves to recommit
the report— I made a few remarks in support of this motion, in the midst of which Howard calls for the orders of the day— The House went into Committee of the whole house on the State of the Union on the Message of P.U.S. and Haynes’s 13 Resolutions. I was Chairman— Some question of order— Cushing wanted to make a Speech on the Resolution of reference to the Committee of Foreign Affairs; but was not ready—he asked to have that Resolution laid aside and the next taken up But Howard objected, and it was required by the rules to proceed first with the Resolutions in their order— Ten of the Resolutions were adopted—the 11th. rejected— Everett made Speeches on that relating to Indian Affairs, and that relating to the Post-Office, but without moving any amendment— Samson Mason made a Speech on the Decision of the Supreme Court in favour of Stockton and Stokes; and Crary of Michigan commenced a Speech in answer to him and to Bell— The Committee rose about 4. O’Clock, and I reported the ten resolutions adopted by the Committee
which were immediately passed by the House— I reported the rejection of the 11th. Resolution; but the Speaker said that was not necessary— Adjourned. Dined at General Baron de Marechal—R. Biddle Bodisco, Fox, Hughes, Krehmer, Mackintosh, Norden Pontois, Preston, Rives, Sergeant, Webster, and four others. Evening party at L. Woodbury’s— Immense crowd. Mrs Madison was going in as I came away—

25. V. Friday— Visits fromVinton and Mr Wilcocks of Ohio— H.R.U.S—further debate on the Resolution reported by Clowney from the Committee on the expenditures of the War Department— I finished my remarks— Mr Lewis had called me out to thank me for what I had said yesterday, and to ask my aid again this daymoved to lay the report on the table which was done— Cushman moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the Union from the Light-house Bill and refer it back to the Committee of Commerce. I enquired why? He said the Committe had received
other applications for Light-Houses, and wished to amend their bill— Objection was made to the recommitment, and it was observed that the Committee might offer any amendment to their bill and have it referred to the same Committee of the whole which have the Bill for consideration— I said after what had been said by the Chairman of the Committee of Commerce I trusted his object was not to take the Bill from the Committee of the whole to suppress it— Cambreleng complained of the enormous expense of the Light-House establishment—said that more than 1200000 dollars had been expended upon it within the last two years, and that their cost in the four or five last exceeded the amount of all that had been spent before upon them since the existence of the Government. The Committee of the whole were discharged from the consideration of the Bill— Private business was taken up after an amendment to the rules proposed by F. Thomas had been adopted—that on the first and
fourth Friday of every month the House will take up private Bills only which occasion no debate—postponing all others— The House went three times into Committee of the whole, M’Kennan, Ingham, and Dromgoole successively in the Chair, and swept off private Bills from the Calendar—all of which were in the House ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow—among them were the Bills for the relief of the legal representatives of William Tudor junr. and for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell— An effort was made to go into Committee of the whole again upon about fifty Bills which still remained on the Calendar—but there was no Quorum— A call of the House was moved and failed, and about 6 the House adjourned— I took Mr Pope home— Whist in the Evening— No Northern Mail— Rainy day.

26. Saturday VI— Edward Cook’s visit— Goes with me to the Capitol— Meeting of joint Smithsonian Committee— Present Senators Robbins, Preston, Benton, Southard of the House Adams, Garland, Thompson, Hunter of Ohio, Charles Shepard— Robbins presents his project— I offer three Resolutions— Thompson makes a question upon the acceptance of the money, on the ground of fraud upon the English Court of Chancery in obtaining the money— Committee agree to meet on Wednesday’s and Saturday’s at 10. O’Clock— To move the House to print Mr Robbins’s paper and my Resolutions and a joint Resolution authorising the Committee to employ a Clerk, and to print necessary papers.— H.R.U.S. Call for Reports from Committees.— I moved the printing of the papers from the joint Committee and also the joint Resolution authorising the Committee to appoint a Clerk and to print necessary papers—adopted without opposition— On the call of the Committee of Manufactures, I moved an amendment to Bill 862. for levying a duty on Starch, to levy a duty of
25 per cent ad valorem upon pins, to be moved as a second Section to the Bill when taken up in Committee of the whole— A motion to print 10,000 copies of a Report from the Committee of Ways and Means, on the condition of the Treasury, was debated. J. Sergeant had obtained the floor for a despatch against the report, but Sergeant was arguing a cause to the Supreme Court, and a motion was made to postpone the subject till next Tuesday, to accommodate him. Debate arose till the expiration of the hour, and Evans called for the orders of the day.— Bills at the third reading—desultory debate— No Quorum— Call of the House till a bare quorum is obtained— Bills passed to the third reading yesterday, taken up, read by their titles and passed— Among them the Bills for the relief of the legal Representatives of William Tudor, and that for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell— Adjourned at 5 Evening at the Theatre—Henry 4. abridged to 3. Acts. Hackett’s Falstaff— Murdoch, Prince Hal— Mrs
Sharpe’s benefit—2—After-Pieces—Day after the wedding—Dix jours de Mariage—The Ransom—Adventure of President Montesquieu. W. S. Smith with me— Met Foster Senator from Tennessee—Martin—Stewart, Cleveland, Patton Waddy Thompson &c— Home at Midnight
27. VI:30. Sunday

Heard Fowler, from John 3.6. Mary Louisa with me— Call on Mrs Tudor. She had been informed by her Grandson Charles T. Stewart of the passage of the Bill for the relief of her Son William’s legal representatives through the House yesterday— Mrs Stewart and Miss Gardiner came in from Church—Mrs. and Miss Gilpin— Mrs Stewart took me into the adjoining dining room, to enquire if it would not be well now for her mother to petition for the outfits— I thought it would be better for her to wait till the bill now just passed in the house shall get through the Senate— Well—she said, she had heard I should be chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs at the next Session of Congress.
It is too far to look forward— I called to see Mr T. B. Johnson; who almost immediately began with the subject of abolition and Slavery— He invited me to dine with him but I was obliged to return home— St. John’s Church after dinner. Mr Hawley read prayers for the 3d. Sunday after the Epiphany, and preached from 1. Corinthians 15.34— North-western gale— Evening cry of fire—
28. V. Monday [symbols]
1. Ioway and Missouri Boundary— Letter of James Davis—
2. Oregonian— Letter from F. P. Tracy— Lynn
3. Anthony Collamore for Levi Everson’s widow Eunice
4— Thomas T. Bailey’s— Bounty Land warrant—

Call on the Commissioner of Pensions, and left with him an affidavit to support the claim of Eunice widow of Levi Everson to a pension— Then on the Secretary of the Navy, with Letters to Midshipmen J. Q. and Joseph H. Adams which I left with him to be forwarded— Then at the Bounty Land Office to enquire of the Land
warrant in favour ofLaurence. He referred me to King and Wilson, Land Agents corner of F. Street—who promised me further information, in a day or two; and he said he had some paper which he wished to submit to my consideration— Call to see a young Man, a Carpenter, who was hurt by running against one of my horses in the Carriage in the rain on Saturday Morning— It was a merciful Providence that he was not run over— His name is Dufief, 19 or 20 years old the only son of his mother, whom I saw— Taylor’s Bookstore for a copy of Bancroft’s History of the United States, advertised last week— He said he had had but 9 copies, all which were sold— H.R.U.S— Haynes moved to suspend the Rules for a Resolution to go into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union, upon the President’s Message—rejected— Resolutions called for; beginning with Maine— I offered a Resolution, requiring the members of the House to produce their credentials before taking their Seats, and providing that in cases of contested elections no member shall vote, till the
House have decided to which of the claimants the Seat belongs— Debate arises and my Resolution lies over— Everett offers a bill on the same subject— Multitudes of Resolutions offered, till the adjournment at 5. O’Clock— Theatre St Mary’s Eve. Celeste the Saltatress. Excellent Actress— La Normande La Cachuca—L’Hirondelle— A Farce— Home at 11.
29. Tuesday VI.15

H.R.U.S— Cambreleng moves to strike out a note at p. 17. from the printed Report from the Committee of Ways and Means on the condition of the Treasury. R. Biddle moves an amendment to recommit the report, to strike out he numerous errors which it contains. Biddle censures very severely the Report— Pickens approves the recommitment and passes a high panegyric on the principles of the Report.
30. VI. Wednesday

Meeting of the joint Committee on the Smithsonian bequest— Present Robbins and Benton of the Senate—Adams, Holt, Ogle, Kennedy, Shepard— Absent of the Senate Preston, Southard,and of the House Thompson, Garland, Hunter of Ohio, and Smith— No Quorum of the Senate’s Committee— Mr Robbins proposed George Sweeny for Clerk, which was assented to by all the members present, and was afterwards agreed to by Mr Garland and Mr Thomson of the House. On consulting Burch, I found the usual allowance for a Clerk to a Committee was 4 dollars a day.— H.R.U.S. The Speaker read a Letter fromHubley of Pennsylvania announcing that he has resigned his Seat in the House— Mr Haynes immediately moved to go in to Committee of the whole House on the State of the Union upon the Message, which was carried without opposition.— Crary who had the floor resumed his speech, and raved about two hours upon Democracy and the Jackson
Administration, and after he closed Waddy Thompson took the floor, and moved that the Committee should rise, which was done, and the House adjourned—
